H0.text: A barometer is not considered an instrument to be used to determine weather.

H1.text: A thermometer is not considered an instrument used to determine weather.

H2.text: An anemometer is not considered an instrument to be used to determine weather.

H3.text: A millimeter is not considered an instrument to determine weather.

A4.text: Barometric pressure and the pressure tendency (the change of pressure over time) have been used in weather forecasting since the late 19th century.

A5.text: Pressure tendency can forecast short term changes in the weather.

A6.text: Thermometers are used in meteorology and climatology in various levels of the atmosphere and oceans.

A7.text: Thermometers are used in roadways in cold weather climates to help determine if icing conditions exist.

A8.text: In meteorology, an anemometer (from Ancient Greek  άνεμος (ánemos) 'wind' and  μέτρον (métron) 'measure') is a device that measures wind speed and direction. It is a common instrument used in weather stations.

A9.text: Plate anemometers have been used to trigger high wind alarms on bridges.

A10.text: Measuring both wind speed and direction using a tagged three-cup sensor

A11.text: A millimetre is a unit of length in the International System of Units (SI), equal to one thousandth of a metre.

A12.text: One millimetre is also equal to 1000 micrometres.
